description.narrative: Output 3.3: Increased capacity at national and sub-national levels for planning, management and budgeting (Capacity Development Partnership Fund), which contributes to Education â€“ General, Equitable Access To Quality Education, Learning And Child-Friendly Schools, Learning Outcomes, Skills Development. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Evaluations, Research And Data, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Improve teaching and learning in relevant, sustainable and inclusive early childhood and basic education services.

mailing-address.narrative: No.11 Street 75 Sangkat Sraschark P.O. Box 176 Phnom Penh

sector.narrative: Education sector planning including coordinating role, SDG 4, etc.
Provision of early learning / pre-primary education teacher training
Provision of multiple-levels (or alternative pathways of education) teacher training
Provision of skills development for adolescents (10-19 year-olds) (including in temporary learning spaces)
System strengthening - community participation and social accountability, e.g. school management committees
System strengthening - inclusive education for children with disabilities

UNICEF Procedure on Harmonized Approach to Cash Transfers to Implementing Partners

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 3.3: Increased capacity at national and sub-national levels for planning, management and budgeting (Capacity Development Partnership Fund)
Percentage of districts achieving a primary completion rate of at least 80%

baseline.value: 130 districts have primary completion rates of at least 80%

target.value: 2015:144 districts will have primary completion rates of 80%

actual.value:
2015:100 out of 197 districts have a primary completion rate of at least 80% (51% of all districts)
In 2013/2014, 130 districts achieved a primary completion rate of at least 80 per cent while in 2014/2015 only 100 districts achieved this. This may partly be due to the fact that over-aged children have

title.narrative: The difference in percentage points between the national primary NER and the average NER of the 30 weakest districts

actual.value:
2015:65.2% average NER across 30 weakest districts
In 2014/2015, there was a 29.3 percentage point difference between the national primary NER of 94.5% and the average NER of the 30 weakest districts. This increased from 23 percentage points in 2013/2014. This shows the need for district-level planning

title.narrative: Execution rate of the education budget

actual.value:
2015:90.3%
The execution rate reduced from 93% in 2013 to 90.3% in 2014 . Nevertheless, there was a net increase of 30 per cent in the total education budget rising to US$346 million (recurrent) in 2014. It is widely acknowledged that the quality of the spending has improved although execution has dec

title.narrative: Roll out of web-based integrated EMIS system with comprehensive and disaggregated data

target.value: 2015:Integrated web-based EMIS system is operational in all provinces

actual.value:
2015:Partially
The new integrated database using more complex software (MySQL Server) was rolled-out in 25 provinces for data entry. Due to some technical issues, the web-based database is being implemented partially in all provinces in conjunction with the old EMIS system of ‘Visual dBase', SPSS and E
